tweets.content: @OpenDataWatch: But to connect the two, open data and statistical communities must be better aligned. Our next #IODC16 workshop tries to bridge this gap.
@od4_d: .@opendatacon pre-event "Openness and National Statistical Offices" today @ 14:30 CEST. cc @WorldBank @ContactPARIS21 @OpenDataWatch #IODC16
@AngieNavarroMX: #opendata next steps: foster linkages, strengthen statistical agencies, grow the community, and the most impt: impact impact impact #IODC16pic.twitter.com/8qQQplSWxB
@seunonigbinde: We need to demonstrate impact, expand data literacy, capacity building, foster linkages & support statistical offices. #IODC16

info: This session aimed at looking into the very challenging intersection between open data and official statistics and how to build bridges between the two communities so they both can take advantage of each other. Some of the panelists key messages were:

session.description: This session will examine the intersection of open data and official statistics. It will be a provocative discussion on the vital role of open data to support Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Experts and government representatives will discuss the challenges and opportunities of open data to leverage production and expand...Read more

conference_notes:
• Eric Swanson (Open Data Watch): “In order to produce the 230 indicators to monitor SDGs timely, reliable, and good data from many different sources, censuses, agricultural surveys, government fiscal accounts, etc. is needed. There is big work ahead because at this moment we are not ready to deliver that data”.
  • Aboubacar Sédikh Beye (National Agency of Statistics and Demography, Senegal): “There are still many challenges left to produce and to make available the basic statistics necessary to create SDGs indicators taking into account that in Senegal 20% of the population does not own birth certificates, for example”.
  • Haishan Fu (World Bank): “There is a bright future as a result of the collaboration between National Statistical Offices and open data community Experts”.
  • Oliver Chinganya (Statistics Economic Commission for Africa): “National Statistical Offices have to come to the forefront of the open data community”.
  • Jeff Chen (U.S. Department of Commerce): “The US Department of Commerce is working with Eurostat and the European Commission to harmonize data and make it comparable”.
name: Open Data and National Statistical Offices: Experiences and Opportunities
